citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee's records of acquisition and disposition are incomplete. Acquisition/inventory on
hand records are missing vital information such as the complete names and addresses of persons from whom dogs were
acquired (four Shit Tzus and four Chihuahuas), sex (one Shih Tzu), date of birth (four Shih Tzus), weight (four Shih Tzus),
description (four Shih Tzus), and date acquired (three Shih Tzus). Two disposition records did not have full names and
addresses for the buyer and seller (one female Chihuahua, one 12-week-old female Shih Tzu); one disposition record
(one female Chihuahua) did not have the date of birth, weight or transport/delivery information. Records containing all of
the required information for animals disposed of or acquired for use in regulated activities are necessary to accurately
track animals to ensure their humane care and use, and to assure the legitimate transfer of ownership. The licensee shall
make, keep and maintain records of acquisition and disposition of all animals that fully and correctly disclose the required
information.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MAY 12, 2023

At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have a written contingency plan in place. Contingency plans and
contingency training for personnel are required to help ensure animal health and well-being in the event of an emergency
or disaster. Without a contingency plan and training on that plan, personnel may not be aware of their roles and
responsibilities; animals may suffer illness, injury or death due to unpreparedness should an emergency or disaster strike.
The licensee must provide a written contingency plan and document training for its personnel regarding their roles and
responsibilities as outlined in the contingency plan and ensure that that new hires receive this training within 30 days of
their start date. The registrant must conduct and document a review of the plan at least once annually; any changes made
during this review must be communicated to employees through documented training within 30 days.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MAY 26, 2023

The playpen used as the primary enclosure for two, 12-week-old male Chihuahua puppies has holes in two of the mesh
walls. The holes are large enough to allow all or parts of the puppies' bodies to pass through.
Primary enclosures with holes such as these pose a risk for escape and/or injury due to entrapment. The licensee must
ensure that primary enclosures are designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound, and
kept in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them securely.
TO BE CORRECTED BY MAY 12, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors 
At the time of inspection, the licensee's records of acquisition and disposition are incomplete.  Acquisition/inventory on 
hand records are missing vital information such as the complete names and addresses of persons from whom dogs were 
acquired (four Shit Tzus and four Chihuahuas), sex (one Shih Tzu), date of birth (four Shih Tzus), weight (four Shih Tzus), 
description (four Shih Tzus), and date acquired (three Shih Tzus).   Two disposition records did not have full names and 
addresses for the buyer and seller (one female Chihuahua, one 12-week-old female Shih Tzu); one disposition record 
(one female Chihuahua) did not have the date of birth, weight or transport/delivery information.  Records containing all of 
the required information for animals disposed of or acquired for use in regulated activities are necessary to accurately 
track animals to ensure their humane care and use, and to assure the legitimate transfer of ownership.  The licensee shall 
make, keep and maintain records of acquisition and disposition of all animals that fully and correctly disclose the required 
information. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MAY 12, 2023 
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning.

At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have a written contingency plan in place. Contingency plans and 
contingency training for personnel are required to help ensure animal health and well-being in the event of an emergency 
or disaster. Without a contingency plan and training on that plan, personnel may not be aware of their roles and 
responsibilities; animals may suffer illness, injury or death due to unpreparedness should an emergency or disaster strike. 
The licensee must provide a written contingency plan and document training for its personnel regarding their roles and 
responsibilities as outlined in the contingency plan and ensure that that new hires receive this training within 30 days of 
their start date. The registrant must conduct and document a review of the plan at least once annually; any changes made 
during this review must be communicated to employees through documented training within 30 days. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MAY 26, 2023 
3.6(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The playpen used as the primary enclosure for two, 12-week-old male Chihuahua puppies has holes in two of the mesh 
walls.  The holes are large enough to allow all or parts of the puppies' bodies to pass through. 
Primary enclosures with holes such as these pose a risk for escape and/or injury due to entrapment.    The licensee must 
ensure that primary enclosures are designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound, and 
kept in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them securely. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY MAY 12, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
